LJava
Class LJ

java.lang.Object
  LJava.LJ

public final class LJ
extends java.lang.Object

Author:
Tzali Maimon The core library of LogicJava.

This is meant to be a singleton. you should use import static when using this library to fully experience how LJ bypass Java's OOP.

Method Detail

world

public static java.util.HashMap<java.lang.Integer,java.util.LinkedHashSet<LJava.Association>> world()
returns a copy of the "world" of rules/facts.

The copy returned has no effect on LJ's "world" besides the fact that they share the objects that appear in their rules' arguments.

So you can change the world you are given but changing the objects in it's rules will effect LJ.

This method tries to return the "latest" version of world possible, so if a rule was added after the method was called it might just slip into the copy but it might as well not.

Besides that there's no worry about Thread-Safety.

Returns:
a copy of the "world" of rules/facts.

                                         java.lang.Object... args)

lz

public static <P,R> LJava.Lazy<R> lz(LJava.Formula<P,R> f,
                                     LJava.Formula<P,P[]> inc,
                                     P... params)
Evaluates a formula f and returns the value of it. The arguments that are used each time are saved internally starting from params and are advanced by the inc Formula after each call to evaluation.

Parameters:
f - - a formula to activate the lazy on
inc - - a formula that increments the inner arguments of f on each lazy evaluation
params - - the start value to start evaluate from.
Returns:
a lazy object returning the type R that is returned from the Formula f

b - - the right query parameters

and

public static LJava.Constraint and(LJ.QueryParameter a,
                                   LJ.QueryParameter b)
This takes two queries and unite them with an AND between them. And is true only when the left query returned an answer that the right side was satisfied by.

It also takes all the possible answers from the right parameter as long as they are legal under the constraints of the left side. in the case of using "all".

And instantiate all the variables in both query parameters.

Parameters:
a - a query parameter (relation or constraint)
b - a query parameter (relation or constraint)
Returns:
A constraint representing the new query

or

public static LJava.Constraint or(LJ.QueryParameter a,
                                  LJ.QueryParameter b)
This takes two queries and unite them with an OR between them. Or is true if either side presents an answer from the "world" which is true.

Parameters:
a - a query parameter (relation or constraint)
b - a query parameter (relation or constraint)
Returns:
A constraint representing the new query

differ

public static LJava.Constraint differ(LJ.QueryParameter a,
                                      LJ.QueryParameter b)
this is equal to not WHERE.

Parameters:
a - a query parameter (relation or constraint)
b - a query parameter (relation or constraint)
Returns:
A constraint representing the new query

where

public static LJava.Constraint where(LJ.QueryParameter a,
                                     LJ.QueryParameter b)
Where operates just like AND with one important difference: it only instantiate the variables in the left parameter thus saving time on searching all the answers of the right side.

It is most useful to use WHERE when the right side is a Formula.

Parameters:
a - a query parameter (relation or constraint)
b - a query parameter (relation or constraint)
Returns:
A constraint representing the new query

isSet

public static boolean isSet(LJava.Variable[] vs,
                            java.lang.Object[] os)
Checks if the LJ variables contains the values in os as their first answer.

For example: if x and y are LJ variables with [1,2] and [2,3] values so inSet([x,y],[1,2]) is true but inSet([x,y],[2,3]) is false.

Parameters:
vs - LJ Variables
os - Objects
Returns:
true if the variables contain the values given in os as their first answer.

isSet

public static boolean isSet(java.lang.Object... args)
pairs up the arguments into vs and os in pairs Variable, Object and activates inSet(vs, os)

Parameters:
args - - arguments
Returns:
inSet(vs,os)

Returns:

same

public static boolean same(java.lang.Object a,
                           java.lang.Object b)
This method should always be used instead of Java's Object.equal method.

This method handles Variables that has values in them as if they were these values. The method consider the first value to mean and the rest do not. So if v is a Variable and O is an object and v hold O as its first value, o.equals(v) will be false but same(o,v) will be true.

Parameters:
a - object
b - object
Returns:
true if objects are the same

deepInvoke

public static java.lang.Object[] deepInvoke(java.lang.Object[] arr,
                                            LJava.Formula f)
Parameters:
arr - an array
f - - Formula
Returns:
an array where the cell i is the result of activating f on arr[i]

undef

public boolean undef(java.lang.Object o)
Parameters:
o -
Returns:
val(o)==undefined

instantiate

public static boolean instantiate(LJava.LJMap varValues)
Tries to instantiate all Variables in the LJMap with the values in that map.

NOTE: LJ Variable turns immutable after first instantiation. So this method returns false if a Variable is already instantiated once it tries to isntantiate it.

That doesn't prevent it from instantiating the other variables.

Parameters:
varValues - LJMap
Returns:
true if successful

setLJProperty

public static void setLJProperty(LJ.Property p,
                                 java.lang.Object v)
Setting the LJProperty to a new value. Watch out. this shouldn't be while threading. Don't change LJ's properties while using its commands in another thread.

Parameters:
p - LJProperty
v - value
